plausible_answers.text: ventricular septal rupture or free wall rupture

qas.question: What does an aneurysm of the left ventricle lead to?
Atrial fibrillation can only be what kind of problem?

context: Complications may occur immediately following the heart attack (in the acute phase), or may need time to develop (a <b3_0>chronic<b3_0/> problem). Acute complications may include heart failure if the damaged heart is no longer able to pump blood adequately around the body; aneurysm of the left ventricle myocardium; <b1_0>ventricular septal rupture or free wall rupture<b1_0/>; mitral regurgitation, in particular if the infarction causes <b2_0>dysfunction of the papillary muscle<b2_0/>; Dressler's syndrome; and <b0_0>abnormal heart rhythms<b0_0/>, such as ventricular fibrillation, ventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation, and heart block. Longer-term complications include heart failure, atrial fibrillation, and an increased risk of a second MI.
